comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Patrick Costen, builder, lived at 21 Manor Street, Waterford in 1901. Its very likely his yard was close by. 1901 Census

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] And Patrick's wife, Susanna was not from Perce, Russian, U S A as it has been transcribed, but Pennsylvania, I'd say!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03]hadn't spotted that and it appears one of his sons was born in the USA, so Mr Costen had spent some time in America and returned home at some point, very interesting.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: According to an article written by Rev. Canon Power in 1943 on Waterfords City walls Mr. Costens yard would have been on the Waterside. Canon Power states that part of the ancient wall formed the West wall of Costen's yard and Mr. Costens office occupied the spot where the walls met the Waterside and a defensive tower once stood. This is the location today g.co/maps/z4t5g

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: An estimate for work by P. Costen dated 3rd of May 1909

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Hey Paul. Replaced the photo above with a higher res (love the receipt, by the way) and found the most amazing thing. All of them have an ivy leaf about their person somewhere, tucked into a button hole, etc.

Could this be to do with Charles Stewart Parnell and Ivy Day? Parnell died on 6 October 1891? This one was taken on 3 October...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Much better Carol, thanks for uploading it. I'd say you are spot on with the ivy and Parnell connection alright and Waterford at the time was very much an Irish Parliamentary Party stronghold.

comment._content: Another Costen related item

comment.author: 52193560@N08
comment._content: Coming from an Architectural background, this shows the great skill of the builders of the time, sadly most of this is now lost and construction industry is just putting together components to make a building that is guaranteed for 25 years!!! OK builders architects and technicians are still skilled people dealing with new safety regulations and energy efficiencies, relying more on design as well as construction, but this picture shows a more romantic image of a time when the skill of the builder and the architect enabled truly wonderful architecture. Sadly money has made everything cheap!!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/paul_wood] I know what you mean. 25 years is a blink of the eye for the buildings (and builders) we celebrate from our photographic collections.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
